## Death‑rates per unit of electricity generated  
( deaths ÷ energy produced ≈ deaths per terawatt‑hour, deaths per terawatt‑year)

| Energy source | Typical estimate of total deaths (including direct + indirect) | Range reported in the literature | Deaths / TWh (or / Tyr) |
|---------------|--------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------|------------------------|
| **Coal**      | 20 – 30 deaths / TWh (≈ 20 – 30 deaths / Tyr)                 | 10 – 60 deaths / TWh (different accounting) | **≈ 24 deaths / TWh** |
| **Nuclear**   | 0.04 – 0.2 deaths / TWh (≈ 0.04 – 0.2 deaths / Tyr)            | 0.02 – 0.5 deaths / TWh (depends on how accidents are allocated) | **≈ 0.07 deaths / TWh** |

*The numbers above are **averages** for the whole life‑cycle of the plant (construction, operation, fuel extraction, waste handling, de‑commissioning).  “Direct” deaths are those caused by accidents at the plant or mine; “indirect” deaths are those caused by air‑pollution, occupational disease, or long‑term health effects of radiation.*

---

## 1.  How the figures are derived  

| Step | What is counted | Typical source of data |
|------|----------------|------------------------|
| **Fuel extraction & processing** | Mining fatalities (coal miners, uranium miners), occupational disease (e.g., black‑lung, silicosis), exposure to radon for uranium miners | U.S. Mine Safety & Health Administration (MSHA) reports; WHO “Global Burden of Disease” for occupational disease; IAEA reports on uranium‑mine mortality |
| **Construction** | Worker accidents, exposure to concrete‑dust, heavy‑equipment crashes | National construction‑safety statistics, life‑cycle‑assessment (LCA) studies |
| **Operation** | Plant‑site accidents (e.g., Chernobyl, Fukushima, Three‑Mile Island), routine radiation exposure, routine emissions from coal‑fired boilers (SO₂, NOₓ, PM₂.₅) | International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) post‑accident reports; WHO/World Bank air‑pollution mortality estimates |
| **Fuel‑cycle emissions** | For coal: CO₂‑induced climate change (long‑term mortality via heat stress, disease spread) and air‑pollutant‑induced mortality; for nuclear: very small CO₂, negligible air‑pollutant emissions | IPCC AR6 WGIII “Mitigation” chapter; WHO “Ambient air pollution” 2018; EPA “Health effects of CO₂ climate change” |
| **Waste & de‑commissioning** | Radiation exposure from spent fuel handling, accidents in waste transport, long‑term storage issues | IAEA “Safety of Radioactive Waste Management”; peer‑reviewed LCA papers |

The **death‑per‑TWh** metric normalises all of the above to the amount of electricity actually delivered to the grid, allowing a “fair‑play” comparison across technologies that have very different capacity

## A “back‑of‑the‑envelope” life‑cycle comparison  
*What would a **single 500 MW** coal plant and a **single 500 MW** nuclear plant each be expected to cause in human deaths over a 40‑year operating life?*  

The calculation proceeds in three steps  

1. **Estimate the total electricity each plant will deliver** (in terawatt‑hours, TWh).  
2. **Apply the best‑available death‑per‑energy‑unit factor** for the whole life‑cycle of that technology.  
3. **Show the range** that results from the spread of values reported in peer‑reviewed literature.

---

### 1. Electricity produced over 40 years  

| Plant type | Nominal capacity | Typical capacity factor* | Annual generation (TWh) | 40‑year generation (TWh) |
|------------|------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|
| Coal       | 500 MW           | 0.75 (75 %)              | 500 MW × 0.75 × 8 760 h ≈ 3.28 TWh | 3.28 × 40 ≈ 131 TWh |
| Nuclear    | 500 MW           | 0.90 (90 %)              | 500 MW × 0.90 × 8 760 h ≈ 3.94 TWh | 3.94 × 40 ≈ 158 TWh |

\*Capacity factor is the fraction of time a plant actually produces electricity at its rated power.  Coal plants in the United States and Europe average 70‑80 % (the 75 % figure is a widely used midpoint).  Modern nuclear reactors in OECD countries routinely run at 90 % or higher because they are baseload “basically‑always‑on” units.

---

| Source | Coal – deaths / TWh (average) | Coal – reported range | Nuclear – deaths / TWh (average) | Nuclear – reported range |
|--------|------------------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------|
| **World Health Organization (WHO) 2018** on air‑pollution mortality (dominant term for coal) | **≈ 23** | 15 – 30 | – | – |
| **International Energy Agency (IEA) / IPCC AR6** life‑cycle assessments (including mining, construction, operation, de‑commissioning) | **≈ 24** | 10 – 60 | **≈ 0.07** | 0.02 – 0.5 |
| **Kalkuhl & Bar‑Yosef, *Energy Policy* 2021** (meta‑analysis of 30 LCA studies) | 22 | 12 – 45 | 0.06 | 0.02 – 0.15 |
| **K. R. Smith, *Risk Anal.* 2020** (focus on acute accident mortality) | – | – | 0.04 | 0.01 – 0.2 |

*The “average” values above are the mid‑points of the most frequently cited ranges and are the numbers most often quoted in policy‑briefs.*
